bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 22, 1941

div1.p: Kean apologizes for a delay in returning to Hench a box of materials and an annotated list. He comments on information that was provided to Hench by Angles and on Hemmeter's article on Carroll. He gives information about where Lazear was buried in Cuba, and about the later transfer of his remains to the United States.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Philip Showalter Hench, January 22, 1941
div1.opener:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Jan. 22 1941
My dear Dr Hench
div1.p:
I am much ashamed of
my long silence. I went away
for Christmas week and on the
day after New Year Day I came
down with influenza. I was not
a very severe attack, but it held
on a long time, with weak legs
and a dull brain and I put
off every thing that I could-
for some days I have felt all
right again, but have only been out
of the house Twice - to funerals, of an
old friend and his wife, who died
during the same week. Now I am
AC
K
2
working off the accumulative of
“must do” 's and have taken up
your box to return it with the
mimeograph (marked as you wished)
and the extracts which I made
from Vol. 5 of my diary. Vol. 5
is a Thicker Volume than the others
and has a lot of things stuck into
it, but as you see very little of the
yellow fever episode. Your letter
of Dec. 30 has been stuck up against
the inkstand on my desk ever since
its arrival on Jan. 2nd to remind
me to answer it. & this is the belated
answer to it, inter alia - And
here and now, lest I forget it, I must
give you my compliments on the
beautifully gotten up printed and
illustrated. “Mile Post-” which came
3
some little time ago. Whether it was
mailed by you or from the college
I am not now certain, by I think
it came in your envelope.
I am especially glad to have your
address and that of Dr Sawyer
in such excellent type to add to
my collection of Walter Reed and
Yellow Fever U.S.S. I hope you sent
a copy to Mr. Clemons, the Librarian
at the Univ of Va. who has a W. Reed &
Y. F. file. I would advise that you write
prominently on the outside “See addresses”
Dr. W. A. Sawyer and Dr. P. S. Hench, which
would guide the Mile Post into that file.
It would be well too to send a note to
Mr. Clemons explaining why you sent it
you cannot refer to the pages, as the Mile
Post has no page numbers.

I stopped at the bottom of the foregoing
page because I was called to lunch &,
when I came back to my little study,
there on the desk was a fat envelope
from you. I am glad that I had made
a good start on the box and this letter
before it came for I am saved an ad-
ditional pang of remorse, if it had come
before I started in on the return of the box.
I sat down at once and read your letter
with its questionnaire and Dr. Angles's
letter. How queerly he has got things
mixed up and he is so perfectly sure
about it. He is perfectly honest and it
shows how very fallible the human mem-
ory is after 40 years! I will write to him
but I am afraid he will think. “Poor old
Commandante Kean! he is certainly in his
dotage”. Now that this letter will give me
some more papers to put into the box
5
I think I will not send it off tonight
as I had in mind, but will keep
it a while longer. I will however send
This off as an evidence of good faith
and good intentions.

I am more and more impressed with
your zeal and acumen in going to the
bottom of things. You are a born researcher.
I may have to employ a stenographer
after all to satisfy your thirst for
meticulous information. I hate to
charge it to you and as, with the
support of a widowed daughter & her child-
dren on my hands, my pay check is
all gone by the end of each month. I
cannot offer to pay the typist myself.
But I will look over the 30 questions
and see - many of them can be answer-
ed very easily and briefly. But when
you bring Hemmeter and Carroll into
AC
K
6
it that is another story and one
of which I knew, at first hand,
very little. Carroll was very care-
ful not to say in my presence any
of the intermations which I heard
he was dropping that the credit
belonged more to him than to Reed
but that the Medical Corps did not
want it to go to a Contract Doctor,
who was not a commissioned officer
and who had been an enlisted man.
I have never seen Hemmeter's article
in James. Carroll & Jam Hemmeter
were class-mates, I have heard, at the
Maryland Medical School, (I am not
sure of its title), where Carroll got his
degree in medicine, and Hemmeter fell
for this disloyal and egotistic talk.
To be continued in our next

I think you may be very sure that Gen. Truby will not object
to your sending me a copy of your letter to him.

closer.seg:
2804 N STREET, N. W.
GEORGETOWN
WASHINGTON, D. C.
Jan 22, 1941
I note in your letter to Gen Truby
of Jan 7 1941 you ask about
the cemetary where Lazear & the
others who died at Columbia
Bks were buried. It was a
poor little temporary place near
the La Playa road he the south
west corner of the reservation.
Lazear's body with the others were
taken up, put into new coffins and
taken to the United States. It was
I think in the autumn of 1900 as
I remember Reed was present
when Lazear's body was exhumed.
J.R.K.
